dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains the concept of swapping two variables in Python, including the underlying idea of temporary storage or tuple unpacking.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Uses simple definitions; shows both the temporary‑variable method and the Pythonic tuple unpacking method with clear step‑by‑step narration.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Gives a vague explanation; mixes up the order of assignments; jumps between unrelated Python topics.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, and energy while demonstrating the swap operation, ensuring learners can follow the code on screen.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear voice, varied tone when highlighting key lines, steady pace that allows viewers to read the code.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone voice, rushes through the code, excessive filler words that obscure the logic.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of the lesson: introduction → problem statement → two solution approaches → live coding → summary.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with a real‑world example, presents the temporary‑variable solution, then shows the concise tuple‑unpacking technique, using transitions between each part.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Randomly jumps between syntax, prints, and unrelated topics; no clear intro or recap.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction with learners, prompting them to predict output, ask questions, or try the swap themselves.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Asks, "What will be the values after this line?"; pauses for viewers to try the code in their own IDE; checks understanding before moving on.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: One‑way lecture with no questions; never invites learners to test the code.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of the presented code and explanations about variable swapping in Python.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Shows syntactically correct Python, correctly explains why tuple unpacking works, and avoids off‑by‑one or naming errors.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Provides code with syntax errors, misstates that `a, b = b, a` swaps without a temporary variable in older Python versions, or mixes up variable names.
